title: 105_s798
content: The Act may be cited as the "Information Technology Worker Shortage Commission Act". Congress recognizes the importance of the information technology industry for the US economy, the need for a sufficient supply of IT workers, and the current shortage of such workers. A collaborative effort is required from businesses, the Federal Government, states, and educational institutions to address this issue. The shortage of information technology workers will persist without collaborative efforts from businesses, the Federal Government, states, and educational institutions. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as "business entity," "Commission," "information technology," and "State." SEC. 4. ESTABLISHMENT OF INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY COMMISSION. The Information Technology Worker Shortage Commission is established with 21 members appointed by the President, Majority Leader of the Senate, and Speaker of the House of Representatives, including a member from the Department of Labor. The Information Technology Worker Shortage Commission is established with 21 members appointed by the President, Majority Leader of the Senate, and Speaker of the House of Representatives. The members include educators, representatives of state governments, and individuals employed in small or average-sized information technology businesses. The Information Technology Worker Shortage Commission is established with 21 members appointed by the President, Majority Leader of the Senate, and Speaker of the House of Representatives. Members shall be appointed for the life of the Commission, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission shall hold its first meeting no later than 30 days after all members have been appointed and will meet at the call of the Chairperson. The Commission shall meet at the call of the Chairperson, with a majority of members constituting a quorum. The Commission will select a chairperson and vice chairperson from among its members. SEC. 5. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with conducting a study on the shortage of information technology workers in the United States, including examining the causes, possible solutions, and comparing programs in the US and other countries to increase the number of IT workers. The Commission will hold public hearings in each region of the United States and consult with the Chief Information Officers Council while conducting a study on the shortage of information technology workers. Existing information related to the issues will be identified and used during the study. The Commission, established under Executive Order No. 13011, will submit a report to the President and Congress by July 1, 1998, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions. They will facilitate the exchange of information among officials of the Federal Government, state governments, educators from higher education institutions, and secondary schools during the study on the shortage of information technology workers. The Commission, established under Executive Order No. 13011, has the power to hold hearings, gather information from Federal agencies, use postal services, and accept gifts. They will submit a report to the President and Congress by July 1, 1998, on the shortage of information technology workers. The Commission members serve without compensation, except for travel expenses allowed at authorized rates. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and staff without following civil service laws. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint and terminate an executive director and additional personnel necessary for the Commission's duties. The executive director's compensation is determined by the Chairperson, not bound by certain pay regulations, and cannot exceed the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint an executive director and additional personnel without exceeding the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. Employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status. Temporary and intermittent services can be procured at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report. $750,000 is authorized for the Commission in fiscal year 1998, with funds available until expended.
